awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research PREEVENTS Track 2: Land-atmosphere feedbacks over urban terrain under heat waves
awd_abstract_narration:
Heat waves are one of the most important causes of weather-related mortality and could lead to unprecedented peak electricity demand. While heat waves are usually instigated by large-scale atmospheric circulation patterns, land-atmosphere feedbacks can further amplify their local magnitudes. However, investigations of land-atmosphere feedbacks over urban areas under heat waves are lacking, despite urban areas being home for over 50% of the global population and 80% of the US population. This project aims to advance the understanding of land-atmosphere feedbacks over urban areas under heat waves and the prediction of local heat wave impacts on natural systems and human activities in urban areas. This project will provide the scientific basis and tools for policy makers to design heat mitigation strategies over the Boston region by engaging policy makers through scientific briefings, workshops and outreach activities. Beyond the tutoring of one graduate student and two postdoctoral researchers, the project will provide summer research opportunities for undergraduate students to participate in interdisciplinary research tackling real urban sustainability challenges. The simulations and analyses generated by this project will be incorporated into various undergraduate and graduate courses that the PIs teach.

In particular, this project focuses on the coupled dynamics and feedbacks between the natural (e.g., vegetation) and built (e.g., buildings) components of the urban environment and the local meteorological conditions under heat waves, and their representations in numerical weather prediction models. New understanding generated by analysis of existing sap flux measurements will be incorporated into the Weather Research and Forecasting (WRF) model to better predict urban evapotranspiration under heat wave conditions. The response of building energy use to heat wave conditions and how the feedback of anthropogenic heat flux further modulates the local meteorological conditions will be also quantified in an iterative manner using WRF and a city scale building energy use model.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

Outcomes Report: Pioneering Research Maps Building Energy Use and Urban Heat for Sustainable Cities

 

Heatwaves are more than just a cause for discomfort; they're a serious health risk and can create intense demands on our power supply. These periods of extreme heat typically start due to broad weather patterns, but the unique interaction between the land and the atmosphere in our cities can make them even hotter.

 

Despite the fact that more than half of the world's population and 80% of people in the United States live in urban areas, there's been surprisingly little research on how these city-specific factors contribute to the severity of heatwaves. Understanding this is crucial because cities not only concentrate people but also heat, leading to potentially dangerous conditions during these already challenging times. In this groundbreaking project, we have developed advanced models to understand and mitigate the impact of urban heat, particularly focusing on how buildings contribute to city temperatures. Through this work, a new approach has been established for evaluating building energy use across entire cities, with Boston as a key study area.

 

The team's innovative methods have allowed them to predict the function of buildings using vast amounts of data, shedding light on energy consumption patterns. They have provided detailed energy models that offer hourly estimates of energy use for individual buildings. These models account for various weather conditions, enabling a precise understanding of how buildings interact with their environment.

 

Particularly noteworthy is the creation of a city-scale model that measures the heat emanating from buildings, known as anthropogenic heat. This information has been instrumental in refining weather forecast models and assessing how urban landscapes cope with heatwaves.

 

Expanding our research to a national scale, the team has produced functional maps of buildings for 50 cities in the United States. The accuracy of these models was verified in cities like Boston and Des Moines. The researchers examined the urban heat island effect, where urban centers become significantly warmer than surrounding areas, analyzing its influence on the cooling requirements of buildings during extreme weather conditions.

 

A key aspect of this study has been the use of weather forecasting and building energy simulations to explore the relationship between human activities and heatwaves. The findings offer critical insights for predicting and managing heatwaves and energy use in buildings more effectively.

 

The project also tackled the social dimensions of urban heat, revealing that the urban heat island effect can have varying impacts on different socioeconomic groups within cities like Boston. This highlights the importance of considering equity in urban planning and the development of intervention strategies.

 

Overall, this research provides a vital toolset for city planners, policymakers, and communities to design smarter, more sustainable cities. By understanding the intricate dance between buildings, energy use, and urban heat, cities can develop strategies to reduce heat emissions from buildings and alleviate the urban heat island effect. As extreme weather events become more frequent due to climate change, such innovations are crucial for enhancing urban resilience and ensuring the well-being of city dwellers.
